review_text: Got the Pixel 9 last week. The camera is stunning and the battery easily lasts a full day, even with 5G and gaming. Only wish it charged a bit faster.
This budget laptop looks good on paper but overheats within 15 minutes of running VS Code and Chrome together. Fans scream and the keyboard gets hot. Regretting this purchase.
The wireless earbuds sound great once they connect, but the Bluetooth randomly drops during every second song. Super annoying because the fit and audio are otherwise perfect.
I bought the Kindle Paperwhite mainly for reading at night. The screen is gorgeous and my eyes don’t hurt anymore, but the UI sometimes lags when opening big books.
Tried the smart air fryer everyone is hyping on Instagram. It burns fries on the default preset and the app disconnects randomly. I ended up using it like a normal oven.
The Sony WH-1000XM6 headphones have insane noise cancellation. I literally can't hear my roommate's loud music now. A bit pricey but totally worth it for focus.
This mechanical keyboard is a mixed bag: the typing feel is amazing and satisfying, but the switches are so loud my friends complain on Discord and my parents hate it.
The cheap action camera claims 4K, but the footage looks like 720p stretched. Colors are washed out and low-light is unusable. Only good thing is that it’s lightweight.
Got the Logitech MX Master mouse for work. Ergonomic shape is perfect, battery lasts forever, and switching between my laptop and tablet is seamless. No complaints.
The fitness band tracks steps and heart rate okay, but the sleep tracking is wildly inaccurate. It says I slept 9 hours when I clearly woke up multiple times.
This Bluetooth speaker is tiny but surprisingly loud. Bass is decent for its size, and it survived a splash near the pool. However, there’s a slight hiss at low volumes.
The new gaming monitor has a 240Hz refresh rate and games feel buttery smooth. But the colors out of the box were oversaturated and I had to tweak the settings a lot.
I bought the budget noise-cancelling earbuds and honestly, the 'noise cancelling' is just marketing. It barely reduces fan noise, and wind sounds even worse when outside.
The Instant Pot clone I bought on sale is surprisingly good. Rice, dal, and pasta all cook consistently, and cleanup is easy. The manual is useless though.
This ring light is fine for casual video calls, but not great for content creation. Brightness is okay, but the color temperature controls barely change anything.
The smartwatch looks premium and the display is beautiful, but the battery dies before the end of the day if I enable always-on display and continuous heart-rate.
Tried the popular productivity app subscription. The UI is clean and the calendar integration is smooth, but half the 'AI features' feel gimmicky and slow.
The new Dyson-style cordless vacuum picks up dust like a beast and is super light to carry up stairs. Only downside is the battery drops fast on max mode.
This budget tablet is decent for YouTube and light browsing, but starts lagging badly when I open more than three apps. For the price, I guess it’s acceptable.
Bought the hardcover edition of 'Atomic Habits'. Content is fantastic and genuinely helpful, but the print quality feels cheap and the pages are already fraying at the edges.
